item.title: Some fun technique I found while doing competitive programming puzzles: Regex DP
item.author: Author
item.description: I do some competitive programming problems for fun, because I have a twisted sense of humor. Recently, I repeatedly encounter a pattern in those problems with a very elegant dynamic programming solution. I haven’t seen anything like this elsewhere, although I’m somewhat aware that regex do use DP. The pattern I’m noticing is more of regex + subsequence. Let’s give a concrete example: Given a sequence of 0 and 1. Supposed that you can choose any [l,r] interval and reverse them (only once).

item.title: Big brain stuff I found on Codeforces
item.author: Author
item.description: There are a lot of big brain solutions on Codeforces. Or maybe I’m just too small-brained or haven’t learned these things yet. This was the problem I found today. As usual, I have no idea how to do this shit (within the time limit). I thought about DP, but then I saw the n <= 10^9. Any dp solution will probably requires at least N^2 - you’ll have to loop from 1 to 10^9, and then you have to find divisors of all number.

item.title: CF Announcement
item.author: Author
item.description: I’m pleased to announce that after long deliberation and hard work, I finally feel comfortable enough to use an anime girl for my Codeforces avatar (handle: NotSponsored) I wanna thanks my ICPC teammate, my ICPC coach, my parents, the pet that I’ll adopt in the future, my country, God and my future employers (assume I’ll have any) for this opportunity. It’s truly a great honor to finally have an anime profile pic for a competitive coding account.
